abstract.p: Given the availability of empirically supported practices for addressing posttraumatic stress disorder and other forms of trauma-related distress, the development and implementation of new technology to deliver these treatments is exciting. Technological innovations in this literature aim to expand availability of empirically based intervention, increase treatment adherence and acceptability, and overcome barriers commonly encountered with conventional trauma-focused treatment. Much of the current research on these technological developments consists of brief reviews and case studies of the separate therapy modalities. Although this work serves to document the appeal and utility of these innovations, it does not provide comprehensive information about the host of options available. To that end, the three general categories of technological advances in trauma therapy (i.e., videoconferencing, e-Health, virtual reality) are reviewed here, including information regarding their empirical support and suggestions for future research and clinical practice.

body.p: The dissemination of empirically supported therapies for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an important task. The lifetime prevalence of PTSD among trauma-exposed individuals is estimated at 6.8% (Kessler, Sonnega, Bromet, Hughes, & Nelson, 1995), and these symptoms can become chronic if left untreated (Foa, Keane, Friedman, & Cohen, 2009), underscoring the need to provide treatment to this population. Those therapies with the most evidentiary support are prolonged exposure therapy (PE; Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007) and cognitive processing therapy (CPT; Resick & Schnicke, 1993). Both approaches use an Emotional Processing Theory (Foa & Kozak, 1986) framework, in which the trauma memory structure is modified with new information (e.g., not all trauma-related cues are inherently dangerous, the individual is now safe) to change the emotions it evokes and result in long-term habituation of distress. PE entails exposure to trauma-related cues within (e.g., retelling the trauma narrative, creating a hierarchy of exposure activities) and between sessions (e.g., completing an exposure activity), with the goal of helping the patient confront the trauma in a safe and systematic manner. CPT also entails exposure to the traumatic event (e.g., written narrative), although the focus is on cognitive restructuring techniques to promote acceptance and acknowledgment of the trauma, as well as address dysfunctional beliefs that may have arisen as a result of the event.

PE and CPT are strongly supported for use with heterogeneous trauma-exposed samples and can result in a significant decrement in PTSD symptoms (e.g., Cahill, Rothbaum, Resick, & Follette, 2009; Ruzek et al., 2004; Solomon, Gerrity, & Muff, 1992). Unfortunately, many individuals do not receive needed treatment. Some barriers to treatment are logistical, such as difficulty accessing a trained mental health care provider, scheduling and keeping regular appointments, and financial limitations (Craske et al., 2005; Dimeff, Paves, Skutch, & Woodcock, 2011; Mechanic, 2002; Mojtabai et al., 2011; Pepin, Segal, & Coolidge, 2009; Sareen et al., 2007). Other roadblocks include personal perceptions about oneself and others, including that one’s symptoms do not necessitate treatment; a lack of knowledge about or confidence in appropriate treatment options; or fear that others will be judgmental about help seeking (Mechanic, 2002, 2007; Mojtabai et al., 2011; Pepin et al., 2009; Sareen et al., 2007). Finally, practitioners themselves may not be trained in empirically supported therapies or perceive that they do not have enough time to use them with patients (Dimeff et al., 2011; Mechanic, 2007). These obstacles can differ widely across geographic areas and populations, but the underlying problem is that trauma-exposed individuals are not receiving the care they need and deserve.

One promising development with respect to overcoming these barriers to care is the use of technology to deliver empirically supported therapies for PTSD to a wide population. These advances work to deliver care to patients (e.g., videoconferencing to conduct therapy sessions via online communication technology, online e-Health interventions for the delivery of therapy and related treatment components) as well as enhance current treatment approaches (e.g., virtual reality [VR] to augment in-session exposure). Because these technologies remain relatively new, many have not been rigorously studied, and extant research is often limited to small samples. Furthermore, there is not yet a sufficient summary of available treatment technology options. Thus, this review provides an overview of more common technologies for trauma-related care in an effort to describe (a) what is available, (b) the research supporting each approach, and (c) implications for continued patient care and research. Of note, although such technologies are used to deliver treatment for a variety of psychological disorders, it is beyond the scope of this article to discuss treatments for disorders other than PTSD.

sec.title: Videoconferencing
sec.p: Secure, encrypted videoconferencing-based technology is a novel technological medium that allows individuals to communicate through a computer monitor or video screen in real time (Germain, Marchand, Bouchard, Drouin, & Guay, 2009). A chief benefit of videoconferencing technology is its capability to display visual and auditory information, thereby offering a suitable proxy for traditional in-person service delivery (Hassija & Gray, 2011). Videoconferencing has emerged as a potentially valuable resource with a number of important applications to mental health, including assessment, consultation, mental health service delivery, clinical supervision, and education and training (Monnier, Knapp, & Frueh, 2003; Richardson, Frueh, Grubaugh, Egede, & Elhai, 2009). Most importantly, videoconferencing is proving to be a particularly valuable resource for individuals in remote locations where specialized mental health services would be otherwise inaccessible. Empirical investigations of videoconferencing have generated initial support for the technology as a feasible and effective means to provide psychological services to diverse client populations (Monnier et al., 2003; Richardson et al., 2009). A burgeoning number of investigations have evaluated the efficacy of videoconferencing as a means to provide psychiatric screening, medication management, and individual- and group-based psychotherapy within trauma-exposed populations.

sec.title: Telepsychiatry
sec.p: A small number of uncontrolled investigations have attempted to evaluate the viability of videoconferencing for the provision of psychiatric services to rural trauma survivors. Thomas, Miller, Hartshorn, Speck, and Walker (2005) found support for videoconferencing as a viable medium for psychiatric screening, evaluation, treatment, and referral among rural domestic violence victims with primarily PTSD and major depressive disorder diagnoses. Findings revealed high client satisfaction with the quality of services provided, and successful rates of evaluation completion and treatment initiation. Similarly, Shore and Manson (2004) described the inception of a telepsychiatry clinic created to provide psychiatric assessments, medication and case management, and brief (i.e., three to five sessions) individual or group psychotherapy for American Indian veterans with PTSD. Results indicated high rates of patient-reported comfort and satisfaction with telepsychiatry services and willingness to use them in the future. Thus, preliminary findings suggest that videoconferencing is a feasible method of providing psychiatric and medication management services to trauma-exposed populations. Inferences drawn from this research are tempered, however, by small sample sizes, lack of symptom assessment, and absence of control conditions.

sec.title: Individual Psychotherapy
sec.p: To date, four studies have evaluated the viability and effectiveness of videoconferencing-based individual therapy among PTSD populations (see Table 1). Evidence generally suggests the efficacy of this medium is equivalent to that of traditional in-person care (Richardson et al., 2009; Sloan, Gallagher, Feinstein, Lee, & Pruneau, 2011). For example, Hassija and Gray (2011) noted large reductions in symptoms of PTSD and depression among rural domestic violence and sexual assault survivors receiving trauma-focused treatment via videoconference; participants also reported a high degree of satisfaction with services (e.g., sound/video quality, confidentiality, perception of sensitivity). A controlled trial conducted by Germain et al. (2009; Marchand et al., 2011) observed that cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) administered to heterogeneous trauma survivors via videoconference resulted in comparable reductions in PTSD, depression, and anxiety symptoms at post-treatment and 6-month follow-up relative to CBT delivered in person. Teleconferencing and CBT groups also evidenced comparable rates of retention. Similar effects were noted when comparing administration of videoconference versus in-person PE to trauma-exposed veterans (Tuerk, Yoder, Ruggiero, Gros, & Acierno, 2010). However, the authors observed that the rate of treatment noncompleters was slightly higher, albeit nonsignificant, in the videoconferencing-based treatment group. By contrast, Gros, Yoder, Tuerk, Lozano, and Acierno (2011) report significantly greater improvement in symptoms of PTSD and depression among veterans receiving in-person exposure treatment relative to those receiving treatment using videoconferencing. However, these authors note that group differences may be due to particularly robust effect sizes for the in-person group, which were nearly twice as large as those typically published (i.e., d = 3.00 and 2.12, for PTSD and depression symptoms, respectively). The authors were unable to test for differences in rates of treatment completion between groups, as there were no attrition data available for the in-person group.

sec.p: In sum, videoconferencing appears to be an effective means for implementing trauma-focused treatment, including those involving exposure techniques. Although slight modifications are necessary when implementing such interventions remotely (e.g., therapy materials are exchanged via e-mail, fax, or postal mail; Tuerk et al., 2010), videoconferencing appears to be a feasible mode of delivering these therapies. Despite some evidence suggesting the superiority of in-person services, videoconferencing also resulted in significant reductions in psychological distress and offers a valuable solution to the plight of trauma-affected individuals in rural areas who would not otherwise receive services. Most importantly, though, videoconferencing appears to be a feasible and safe medium to provide the best-practices treatments for PTSD.

sec.title: Group-Based Psychotherapy
sec.p: Videoconferencing has also garnered support as a useful medium to provide group-based psychological treatment (see Table 1). In the investigations reviewed, participants presented for treatment in local clinics and the therapist provided treatment either in person or remotely, via videoconferencing. In a small randomized controlled trial (RCT), Morland, Pierce, and Wong (2004) demonstrated comparable rates of PTSD symptom reduction and treatment retention in Pacific Island veterans assigned to an in-person or videoconference-based coping skills group intervention. Secondary analyses suggested equivalent rates of attrition, treatment adherence, cohesion, and satisfaction across conditions, although the videoconferencing group did report somewhat lower perceived treatment credibility, therapeutic alliance, and affiliation with the facilitator than the in-person group (Greene et al., 2010). Frueh et al. (2007) failed to detect differences in trauma and depressive symptoms at post-treatment or 3-month follow-up among combat veterans receiving in-person or videoconference-based group CBT. Rates of treatment completion were equivalent and perceptions of service delivery (e.g., comfort within the group, overall satisfaction) were generally comparable, although the in-person group reported significantly greater comfort in talking with their therapist at post-treatment. These data suggest that videoconferencing is an efficacious and feasible means of providing group-based psychological treatment to trauma survivors. However, lower perceptions regarding the quality of the therapeutic relationship relative to in-person treatment suggest that additional efforts to improve relationships between the therapist and group members may be necessary.

sec.title: Summary and Directions for Future Research
sec.p: Videoconferencing is emerging as a viable method for providing psychiatric care, as well as individual and group-based trauma interventions, within underserved and geographically remote populations. Although some studies suggest superior gains with respect to symptom improvement (i.e., Gros et al., 2011) and patient perceptions of therapeutic alliance (i.e., Frueh et al., 2007; Greene et al., 2010) for in-person services, most studies reported high levels of patient satisfaction with videoconferencing treatment and comparable rates of treatment retention. Importantly, though, videoconferencing resulted in meaningful improvement in the majority of studies. Furthermore, it is worth noting that, for rural trauma survivors seeking mental health services, the relevant comparison is no psychological services at all. Accordingly, videoconference technology affords not only convenience but also a means to specialized mental health services for underserved and rural populations. Although encouraging, data should continue to be interpreted cautiously, as the majority of existing studies were conducted using small samples of trauma-exposed individuals with no randomization to intervention. Additional RCTs comparing videoconferencing and in-person treatment are warranted, and inclusion of larger samples and structured clinical interviews are needed to strengthen conclusions drawn from this literature.

Provision of services via videoconferencing is also associated with a number of perceived challenges regarding the impact of distal services on the therapeutic alliance, confidentiality, and patient safety (e.g., Manhal-Baugus, 2001). Although many of these challenges are not unique to videoconferencing-based services per se, a number of procedures are recommended to maintain adherence to ethical guidelines (see Barnett & Scheetz, 2003; Fleming, Edison, & Pak, 2009; Manhal-Baugus, 2001). Recommendations for patient safety include conducting comprehensive intake procedures to assure appropriateness for treatment (Manhal-Baugus, 2001) and ensuring patients and providers access to on-site mental health providers and security staff (Tuerk et al., 2010). Providers should also have information for local community resources (e.g., shelter, police department), should they be needed. Technical difficulties also become a logistical issue for electronic services, and a contingency plan (e.g., completing the session via telephone) should be established to avoid interruption of service delivery (Hassija & Gray, 2011). Finally, since some may find this method of service delivery unappealing, clinicians should discuss videoconferencing with their patients and address any concerns they have about this method of service delivery to determine their suitability for this medium.

sec.title: e-Health
sec.p: The delivery of therapeutic interventions via the Internet (i.e., e-Health) stands to provide significant contributions to the field by allowing greater access to empirically supported care. Such interventions can be readily standardized for wide dissemination without attenuation of their power across the number of individuals served or increasing their cost with respect to therapist time and effort (Munoz, 2010). Dissemination can also be achieved in the acute aftermath of a traumatic event (Benight, Ruzek, & Waldrep, 2008), helping to reduce the public health burden of posttrauma symptoms (Christensen, 2010; Kazdin & Blase, 2011). Internet services may also improve the standard of living by providing services to those in need at any time, thus reducing mental health care disparities by overcoming barriers to care (e.g., stigma, inability to access a qualified provider; Bennett & Glasgow, 2009; Christensen, 2010; Dimeff et al., 2011; Kazdin & Blase, 2011; Munoz, 2010). Finally, these technologies afford unique research benefits, including high fidelity to treatment protocols (Christensen, 2010; Dimeff et al., 2011), the ability to rapidly update information, and facilitated data collection, coordination, and dissemination (Clough & Casey, 2011; Taylor & Luce, 2003). Importantly, investigations of e-Health indicate that it is an effective and viable form of treatment.

Considering that of the 74% American adults who use the Internet, 80% search health-related information and 25% track health-related data (e.g., weight; Cox, 2011), the potential impact of e-Health interventions is substantial. Such interventions vary widely with respect to content, duration, and structure, ranging from stand-alone automated therapies with individual tailoring (e.g., screening patients into specific modules) and therapist support (e.g., phone calls, e-mails), to programs that are designed as adjuncts to traditional, in-person care, and prevention or maintenance efforts (Munoz, 2010). Empirically based techniques, such as PE and CPT, are particularly suited to computerized delivery because of their standardization and emphasis on skills training (Christensen, 2010; Proudfoot, 2004).

Reviews of extant trauma-related e-Health interventions are generally quite positive (Amstadter, Broman-Fulks, Zinzow, Ruggiero, & Cercone, 2009; Barak, Hen, Boniel-Nissim, & Shapira, 2008; Benight et al., 2008), although positive results are not always observed (e.g., Bugg, Turpin, Mason, & Scholes, 2009). With respect to specific interventions, Klein et al. (2009; 2010) conducted two uncontrolled evaluations of PTSD Online, a 10-week CBT program with therapist support by e-mail, within a trauma-exposed community sample. Significant reductions (Jacobson & Truax, 1991) in self-reported PTSD symptoms were observed at post-test, corroborated by clinician-rated PTSD status at post-test and 3-month follow-up (2010; see Table 2). Lange et al. (2000), Lange et al. (2003), and Lange, van de Ven, Schrieken, and Emmelkamp (2001) reported similar effects within trauma-exposed Dutch samples using Interapy, a 5-week writing exposure protocol that includes cognitive restructuring. Improvements at post-test and a 6-week follow-up were shown in controlled (i.e., waitlist control condition) and uncontrolled studies with evidence of clinically significant change for the majority of participants (2000, 2001). Knaevelsrud and Maercker (2007) also showed significant improvement in PTSD and other psychological symptoms in a RCT comparing Interapy to a waitlist control condition in Dutch community members with PTSD. Improvements were evident at post-test, as well as at a 5-week (2007) and 18-month follow-up (2010).

sec.p: Hirai and Clum (2005) conducted a RCT using the only intervention without therapist feedback. This exposure-based CBT program resulted in improvement in the frequency and intensity of trauma symptoms relative to a waitlist control condition within a community sample. However, clinically significant improvement was only found with respect to trauma-specific avoidance and other clinical domains (e.g., depression symptoms, trauma-specific coping). Finally, Litz, Engel, Bryant, and Papa (2007) conducted a RCT comparing DE-STRESS, an e-Health exposure-based CBT intervention, to online supportive counseling among military service members diagnosed with combat- or terror-related PTSD. DE-STRESS participants evidenced significantly lower PTSD and depression symptoms at posttest, and many no longer met diagnostic criteria for PTSD. Although there was not a significant difference between groups at the 3-month follow-up, the DE-STRESS group reported significantly fewer symptoms of PTSD, depression, and anxiety at the 6-month follow-up.

Taken together, e-Health interventions show remarkable promise with respect to trauma treatment. Although a survey of patients not actively seeking treatment found that face-to-face or telephone-based treatments were preferred to e-Health, those individuals who reported barriers to treatment (i.e., cost, time) preferred e-Health, underscoring the importance of this technology in circumventing roadblocks to care (Mohr et al., 2010). Importantly, participants who actually used these services report satisfaction with e-Health (Klein et al., 2009; Knaevelsrud & Maercker, 2007; Lange et al., 2003) and positive perceptions of closeness with their therapists (Klein et al., 2009; Knaevelsrud & Maercker, 2007). Yet, results should be interpreted with caution, given that these interventions vary with respect to format and delivery, and are often examined with small convenience samples that may not have PTSD. In addition, aside from the Litz et al.’s (2007) study, comparison groups are limited to a waitlist control condition.

sec.title: Summary and Directions for Future Research
sec.p: Development and evaluation of e-Health interventions is of great importance, given the burgeoning interest in, and access to, the Internet (Boschen, 2009; Clough & Casey, 2011; Dimeff et al., 2011). As discussed, not only have e-Health interventions been shown to be effective with respect to symptom reduction in RCTs but also these services can be used to provide treatment to those who would not otherwise receive it. Importantly, patients in e-Health interventions report positive perceptions of the technology, possibly due to their familiarity with it (e.g., Clough & Casey, 2011; Klein et al., 2009; Klein et al., 2010; Knaevelsrud & Maercker, 2007; Ruggiero et al., 2006), and treatment drop-out rates are similar to those of in-person treatment (Melville, Casey, & Kavanaugh, 2010).

Many concerns have arisen about e-Health, including logistical (e.g., attrition, underengagement) and ethical (e.g., health disparities, user-identity assurance, privacy, crisis management) issues (e.g., Atienza et al., 2007; Barak et al., 2008; Christensen, 2010; Dimeff et al., 2011). However, these problems are being addressed (Bennett & Glasgow, 2009; Dimeff et al., 2011; Proudfoot, 2004; Tuerk et al., 2010), including those relevant to trauma-exposed populations. Among these, automated or therapist-generated reminders can be used to decrease avoidance and increase accountability (Litz et al., 2004), and interventions that allow for individual tailoring to the patient’s symptom presentation (Christensen, 2010; Taylor & Luce, 2003) meet the need for a more flexible treatment approach (Lange et al., 2003). Increased mental health care disparities due to these technological advances are a concern, given limited access to technology in some populations (Atienza et al., 2007; Gibbons, 2005), as well as the possibility that vulnerable populations may be led astray with respect to treatment options (Atienza et al., 2007; Proudfoot, 2004). As such, it is incumbent upon researchers and clinicians to ensure that technologies are developed thoughtfully and that continued education regarding appropriate treatment options is used for dissemination within appropriate populations. Of note, some patient populations who historically report little interest in technology (e.g., ethnic minorities, older individuals; Hardiker & Grant, 2011) may benefit from additional support when using e-Health or may not be suitable candidates for these interventions. Continued use and refinement of these interventions will assist in the development and dissemination of procedures to address other ethical and logistical issues as they arise.

Further empirical evaluations are greatly needed in this area, including the use of broader, more generalizable participant populations (Taylor & Luce, 2003), particularly those individuals diagnosed with PTSD. Research should also address the theoretical underpinnings of intervention development, and the timing and additional support needed for a successful e-Health intervention (Amstadter et al., 2009; Benight et al., 2008). One additional promising, yet untested, technology in this area is m-Health, or the use of mobile devices (e.g., cell phones) to deliver components of therapy. This technology allows for convenient symptom tracking and reminders, as well as ready access to therapeutic tools and support (e.g., intervention content, therapist contact; Boschen, 2009; Boschen & Casey, 2008; Dimeff et al., 2011; Kazdin & Blase, 2011; Proudfoot, 2004). Although applications such as PTSD Coach (National Center for PTSD, 2011) exist and reviews of it are positive (Department of Veterans Affairs, 2011), there is not yet empirical research on these interventions, leaving substantial room for contributions in this area.

sec.title: Virtual Reality
sec.p: VR technologies have received increasing attention over the past decade as a supplement to traditional exposure-based interventions for PTSD. VR platforms developed for the treatment of PTSD provide a variety of visual, auditory, tactile, and olfactory stimuli intended to facilitate habituation through heightened engagement with the trauma memory. Elements of VR address a number of barriers encountered with conventional exposure. First, increased activation of the trauma network is believed to help avoidant individuals fully engage with trauma memories (Rothbaum et al., 1999). Second, VR technologies may be programmed to provide exposure to cues that would otherwise be difficult or impossible to access (e.g., combat environments) and last for a duration sufficient to achieve habituation, which can be difficult for some traumas (e.g., dangerous driving scenarios). Third, VR provides a novel alternative for individuals reluctant to participate in conventional exposure-based interventions. Emerging evidence suggests that clinicians and patients rate VR-assisted interventions as a viable alternative to traditional psychotherapy (Kramer et al., 2010; Wilson, Onorati, Mishkind, Reger, & Gahm, 2008) and that patients reluctant to engage in traditional face-to-face therapy may be willing to participate in VR-based interventions (Wilson et al., 2008).

Rothbaum and colleagues (Ready, Gerardi, Backscheider, Mascaro, & Rothbaum, 2010; Ready, Pollack, Rothbaum, & Alarcon, 2006; Rothbaum et al., 1999; Rothbaum, Hodges, Ready, Graap, & Alarcon, 2001; Rothbaum, Ruef, Litz, Han, & Hodges, 2004) provided the first evidence for the utility of VR as an aid to exposure in the treatment of PTSD. The Virtual Vietnam platform developed for this research serves as a prototype for VR-assisted interventions for PTSD. This head-mounted display is equipped with headphones and digital screens and is immersive in that all stimuli available to the user are generated by the system. Two virtual environments with related sensory cues are available: an open field with swamps, hills, and wooded areas similar to those encountered in Vietnam, and a simulated helicopter transport over Vietnamese terrain. During exposure trials, patients provide a first-person narrative of the trauma memory as they navigate the virtual environment. Sensory effects available within each environment (e.g., gunfire, explosions, radio chatter, take-off, and landing of the helicopter transport) are manipulated by a clinician to approximate experiences detailed in the trauma narrative. These effects are controlled by the provider who maintains contact with the user via a microphone located in the headset. Virtual exposures continue until reductions in distress are observed.

Since the introduction of Virtual Vietnam, additional programs have been developed to augment exposure within specific trauma populations. Programs available for combat trauma include Virtual Baghdad (McLay et al., 2011; McLay, McBrien, Wiederhold, & Wiederhold, 2010; Wood et al., 2007), Virtual Iraq/Afghanistan (Gerardi, Rothbaum, Ressler, Heekin, & Rizzo, 2008; Reger et al., 2011; Reger & Gahm, 2008; Rizzo et al., 2009), and a VR system for veterans of the Portuguese Colonial Wars (Gamito et al., 2007; Gamito et al., 2010). With respect to terror-related trauma, platforms are available for survivors of car bombings (Freedman et al., 2010) and the World Trade Center attacks (Difede et al., 2007; Difede & Hoffman, 2002). Multiple simulators for motor vehicle trauma have also been developed (Beck, Palyo, Winer, Schwagler, & Ang, 2007; VR World Highway, Sariava et al., 2007). Finally, Botella et al. (2010) describe EMMA’s World, a novel system incorporating a collection of flexible virtual environments. In EMMA’s Room, a virtual screen displays person-specific stimuli (e.g., three-dimensional objects, sounds, images, videos) uploaded to augment imaginal exposure. The Book of Life is a virtual text in which users detail memories of the traumatic event. Finally, a series of virtual landscapes (e.g., beach, sunny prairie, desert) are available to help represent emotional content during treatment. EMMA’s World is unique in that environments available in this system may be modified to address psychopathology in a range of trauma populations.

A growing literature provides evidence for the effectiveness of these tools. Case studies detailing the treatment of combat, terror, and motor vehicle trauma are generally encouraging (Difede & Hoffman, 2002; Freedman et al., 2010; Gerardi et al., 2008; Reger & Gahm, 2008; Rothbaum et al., 1999; Sariava et al., 2007; Tworus, Szymanska, & llnicki, 2010; Wood et al., 2007), although marginal responses are reported in some cases (e.g., Gamito et al., 2007; Rothbaum et al., 2004). Reductions in Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale (CAPS; Blake et al., 1990) scores among treatment completers range from 34.4% to 100.0%, with the majority of cases achieving criterion for clinically significant change (i.e., Schnurr, Friedman, Lavori, & Hsieh, 2001). Similar effects are noted with respect to self-reported symptoms (13.6%-90.0%). Although differences in patient characteristics, trauma type, VR platform, and protocol adherence contribute to variability in treatment response across single-case research, this literature offers preliminary evidence for the efficacy of VR-assisted exposure.

Uncontrolled clinical trials provide additional support for the efficacy of VR-assisted exposure. Ready et al. (2006) documented positive treatment response to Virtual Vietnam across two separate trials, the first of which was reported by Rothbaum et al. (2001). Across both trials, medium to large effects were noted for pre- to posttreatment CAPS reductions among treatment completers (see Table 3). Rizzo et al. (2009) and Reger et al. (2011) report similarly large effects in self-reported symptomatology among active duty service members using the Virtual Iraq/Afghanistan platforms. Data from the Reger et al. trial are particularly impressive, given that over half of participants were referred following previous treatment nonresponse. Similar effects are noted in survivors of motor vehicle trauma (Beck et al., 2007).

sec.p: Effects from controlled clinical trials largely parallel those noted within uncontrolled research (see Table 3). Difede et al. (2007) observed that pre- to posttreatment CAPS reductions following VR-assisted exposure were superior to a waitlist control condition among survivors of the World Trade Center attacks. Again, half of treatment completers in this study were referred to VR-assisted exposure following nonresponse to PE. Other trials utilizing active comparison conditions suggest that VR-assisted exposure performs at least as well as other empirically supported interventions (e.g., Botella et al., 2010; McLay et al., 2010).

A collection of small RCTs offer mixed support for the efficacy of VR-assisted interventions (see Table 3). Gamito et al. (2010) found marginal reductions in pre- to posttreatment CAPS scores for older veterans assigned to VR-assisted exposure, but no group effects were noted relative to veterans assigned to imaginal exposure alone or a waitlist control. Similarly, Ready et al. (2010) randomized older veterans to Virtual Vietnam or person-centered therapy conditions. Reductions in pre- to posttreatment CAPS scores were noted in the sample as a whole, but no significant changes emerged when conditions were examined individually. By contrast, McLay et al. (2011) report greater overall CAPS reductions among active-duty service members participating in the Virtual Baghdad system relative to standard care.

sec.title: Summary and Directions for Future Research
sec.p: As a whole, data evaluating the efficacy of VR-assisted exposure programs are promising. Although research utilizing randomized controlled methodology offers the least conclusive data with respect to overall effectiveness, results should be interpreted within the context of the limited samples available in this research (i.e., n from 5 to 10). The larger literature provides evidence of pre- to posttreatment symptom reductions characterized by medium to large effect sizes. Follow-up data suggest the durability of gains at 3- and 6-months post-treatment (Difede et al., 2007; Freedman et al., 2010; Ready et al., 2006; Ready et al., 2010; Rizzo et al., 2009; Rothbaum et al., 1999; Rothbaum et al., 2001). Furthermore, VR interventions appear acceptable to clinicians and patients, and evidence effectiveness in populations that are historically difficult to treat (e.g., older combat veterans, active duty military, previous treatment nonresponders). The existing data are inconclusive as to whether VR-assisted interventions provide additional benefit beyond established exposure-based therapies for PTSD. Given that VR technology is generally conceptualized as a tool to facilitate—as opposed to replace—traditional exposure, ongoing research may be best directed toward isolating subsets of the trauma population in which VR may be particularly beneficial. Examples include patients who are reluctant or unable to adequately engage with trauma memories due to extreme avoidance, individuals for whom volitional recall of the event is compromised by head injury or other cognitive insult, cases where safely conducting in-vivo exposure is difficult or unmanageable (e.g., stressful or dangerous driving situations), and individuals who are unwilling to participate in conventional psychotherapy due to stigma or previous treatment failure. Evidence for the utility of VR-assisted exposure in these specific populations may offset increased cost associated with these interventions.

A number of caveats to VR-assisted exposure also warrant mention. Despite support for the effectiveness of VR-based exposure, a number of caveats should be noted. Access is a primary limitation to widespread implementation of these interventions. Unlike other technological advancements in the treatment of PTSD (e.g., videoconferencing, web-based interventions), increasing access to care has not been a major aim of VR-assisted exposure. Treatment is also limited to the extent that VR platforms are not currently available for many forms of trauma (e.g., child abuse, sexual assault). Even among events for which systems have been developed, the degree to which VR environments are able to approximate person-specific experience is unclear. Finally, several factors could preclude patients as viable candidates for VR-based intervention (e.g., motion sickness, claustrophobia, dissociative tendencies). Despite these caveats, VR-assisted interventions represent an exciting progression in psychological care, and ongoing advancements are expected to facilitate their use in clinical practice over the coming years.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Technological advances in the treatment of trauma stand to provide a number of benefits. Importantly, developments including videoconferencing and e-Health can be used to reach patients with barriers to care (e.g., stigma, language, location). In addition, these technologies can be used to deliver empirically based treatments for PTSD. In addition to treating the presenting symptoms, e-Health may also be incorporated into a stepped care system (e.g., Christensen, 2010; Dimeff et al., 2011; Munoz, 2010; Ritterband & Tate, 2009), thus helping with early intervention and prevention, as well as decreasing the public health burden of psychological symptoms. VR technology, although not focused on dissemination of care, offers an increasingly viable tool to circumvent difficulties that commonly arise over the course of therapy (e.g., avoidance, difficult trauma to access via exposure). As a whole, these technologies promise greater access to, and quality of, empirically supported care among trauma survivors.

These advancements are particularly important within the context of care for rural patients. The applicability of videoconferencing and e-Health interventions to individuals who might not otherwise have access to care is clear. However, the availability of these services may be impacted by a number of factors, including access to needed technology (e.g., proximity to a facility that uses teleconferencing, internet service in the home; Schooley, Horan, Lee, & West, 2010) as well as provider access to training for these services (Bennett-Levy & Perry, 2009). To address these potential barriers, widespread efforts include expanding access to technology in rural areas (Bailey, 2009) and increasing the mental health education of, and targeted treatments to, rural populations (Griffiths & Christensen, 2007). Coordination with community agencies and between-care providers is also important in helping to identify individuals who would likely benefit from care and connect them to services (Wendel, Brossart, Elliott, McCord, & Diaz, 2011). Increasing coordination between care providers can also help ensure that these individuals receive needed trainings (Schooley et al., 2010), which may be provided through additional technological advances, such as online training programs (Bennett-Levy & Perry, 2009).

Given the relatively recent inception of these developments, the empirical research regarding their effectiveness is limited. However, as reviewed, there is preliminary support for the use of videoconferencing, e-Health, and VR with trauma survivors (see Tables 1-3). Suggestions are made with respect to continued research, particularly RCTs with larger generalizable populations. This area will continue to grow as more programs are developed (e.g., e-Health, m-Health, VR), and as these technologies become more widely recognized and available. As reviewed, despite the ethical and logistical concerns that arise with each technology, many of these concerns are not unique to this form of care and the field continues to advance as methods for overcoming these issues are developed.

Perhaps one of the most encouraging aspects of these advances in treatment is the willingness of patients to use them. The majority of research that assessed patient interest in the technology shows positive perceptions of it (e.g., Frueh et al., 2007; Grubaugh, Cain, Elhai, Patrick, & Frueh, 2008; Hassija & Gray, 2011; Klein et al., 2009; Knaevelsrud & Maercker, 2007; Kramer et al., 2010; Proudfoot et al., 2010), including a willingness to use it instead of traditional treatment (e.g., Wilson et al., 2008). Given the public interest in, combined with the effectiveness of, these technologies, they appear to represent a new generation of treatment. Continued developments in this field are exciting, as these technologies stand to provide significant benefit to patients, and most importantly, provide access to empirically supported care for all trauma survivors, regardless of barriers to care.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Lisa A. Paul, PhD, is an assistant professor at Northern Illinois University. She completed her internship and postdoctoral fellowship at the National Crime Victims Research and Treatment Center in Charleston. Her primary research interests are in trauma disclosure and the development of empirically supported and theoretically grounded interventions to support disclosure recipients.

Christina M. Hassija, PhD, is a postdoctoral fellow at the National Center for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder through the VA Palo Alto Health Care System and Stanford University. Her primary research interests are identifying risk and resiliency factors associated with interpersonal assault-related posttraumatic stress disorder, and the development and dissemination of evidence-based trauma-related interventions.

Joshua D. Clapp, MA, is a student at the University of Buffalo, State University of New York, and an intern at the National Crime Victims Research and Treatment Center at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston. His research interests include trauma-related affective processes and the impact of posttrauma psychopathology on interpersonal functioning.
